title: Starfire Sports
text:
Starfire Sports is a <a href="multi-purpose%20stadium">multi-purpose stadium</a> and sporting facility in <a href="Tukwila%2C%20Washington">Tukwila, Washington</a>, United States. It is located on the banks of the <a href="Green%20River%20%28Duwamish%20River%29">Green River</a>, just south of <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a>. The stadium is operated by the <a href="non-profit%20corporation">non-profit corporation</a> Starfire Sports and is home to several soccer and rugby teams.
At the time of its opening, CEO Chris Slatt claimed it was "the largest synthetic-turf soccer complex in the U.S." The <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">MLS</a> team <a href="Seattle%20Sounders%20FC">Seattle Sounders FC</a> has offices and training facilities at the complex, and stages <a href="Lamar%20Hunt%20U.S.%20Open%20Cup">Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup</a> matches at the main stadium. Their affiliate team, <a href="Seattle%20Sounders%20FC%202">Seattle Sounders FC 2</a>, played at Starfire from 2015 to 2017. The Seattle franchise of <a href="Major%20League%20Rugby">Major League Rugby</a>, the <a href="Seattle%20Seawolves">Seattle Seawolves</a>, began play at Starfire Sports in spring 2018.
History.
The site was formerly <a href="Fort%20Dent">Fort Dent</a> <a href="Park">Park</a>, operated by <a href="King%20County%2C%20Washington">King County</a>. In addition to the existing grass soccer fields, the park included a <a href="cricket">cricket</a> pitch and softball fields in the areas now occupied by artificial-surface soccer fields. Severe budget cuts in 2002 led the county to schedule the closing of this park, among others, at the end of the year; however, parks that were located within <a href="municipal">municipal</a> boundaries were offered to those cities. That offer sparked the formation of Starfire Sports by Slatt, Steve Beck and Mark Bickham, who negotiated a 40-year <a href="lease">lease</a> with the city of Tukwila to allow them to build and operate the complex. This would relieve the city of an estimated $500,000 in annual <a href="Maintenance%2C%20repair%20and%20operations">maintenance</a> costs which would likely have caused it to refuse the county’s offer had Starfire not stepped in. Starfire plans to cover operating and maintenance costs through user fees and <a href="advertising">advertising</a> banners and hopes to retire the $10 million construction costs over the course of several years.
New construction included four lighted outdoor soccer fields with <a href="FieldTurf">FieldTurf</a>, including the stadium with its 2000-seat grandstand, along with the indoor facility.
Beginning in summer 2004, English <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> powerhouse <a href="Manchester%20United">Manchester United</a> offered training at Starfire as part of their Soccer Schools program. This came to an end in December 2007.
The city of Tukwila still maintains a wooded part of the site as a public park. An expansion was unanimously approved by city leaders in a public hearing at the beginning of 2008 for the offices and training facilities of <a href="Seattle%20Sounders%20FC">Seattle Sounders FC</a>.
Facilities.
Starfire features fields for indoor and outdoor <a href="soccer">soccer</a>, and occasionally <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> games, as well as a 4,500-seat soccer stadium previously used by the <a href="United%20Soccer%20Leagues">USL</a> <a href="Seattle%20Sounders%20%281994%E2%80%932008%29">Seattle Sounders</a> and the <a href="Seattle%20Reign%20FC">Seattle Reign FC</a> of the <a href="National%20Women%27s%20Soccer%20League">NWSL</a> and now used by the <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">MLS</a> <a href="Seattle%20Sounders%20FC">Seattle Sounders FC</a> for <a href="US%20Open%20Cup">US Open Cup</a> matches, the <a href="Seattle%20Sounders%20FC%202">Seattle Sounders FC 2</a> of the <a href="United%20Soccer%20League">United Soccer League</a>, the <a href="Seattle%20Sounders%20Women">Seattle Sounders Women</a> of the <a href="USL%20W-League">W-League</a>, and is the home pitch for the <a href="Seattle%20Seawolves">Seattle Seawolves</a>, <a href="Major%20League%20Rugby">Major League Rugby</a> team. It was also the home of <a href="Hibernian%20Saints">Hibernian and Caledonian F.C.</a> and <a href="FK%20Pacific">FK Pacific</a> of the <a href="Pacific%20Coast%20Soccer%20League">Pacific Coast Soccer League</a>. Additionally the complex hosts the annual <a href="All%20Nations%20Cup">All Nations Cup</a>. The stadium field in 2004 became only the eighth American artificial-surface pitch to earn "recommended" status by <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> and was thereby sanctioned for international play.
The complex has an indoor facility which has two <a href="indoor%20soccer">indoor soccer</a> <a href="FieldTurf">FieldTurf</a> fields. It also hosts administrative offices, a Mad Pizza restaurant, and a game room for children.
The expansion undertaken by the complex in 2008 also included new fields along with a workout and fitness area for the Sounders FC, as well as offices for the coaching and technical staff. To retain its community-based programs and accessibility, these areas and the fields have some public access.
